text.tspan: downloaded, so they can be added
All GPG MIME parts are hidden;
they are not shown as attachments.
Since messages that are either signed or encrypted messages are generally
signed and/or encrypted by the sender, and since the sender already features
prominently in the UI, the signed/encrypted status should be displayed next
to the sender. This can be done with variations of the existing stock symbolic
For senders with known good keys, but who did not sign or encrypt the
For senders with known good keys who signed (but not encrypted) the
For senders with known good keys who encrypted (and maybe signed) the
For senders with broken, expired, or otherwise problematic keys:
For senders without any known keys:
The status icon should be part of the sender's address label, so that when
the user clicks either, the contact popover is shown.
The popover should include an item with the same status icon so as to,
reinfoece the meaning of the icon, and some short text describing the
status. Clicking the item can show a dialog with more detailed information
about the verification/encryption, the keys involved and their trust leves,
etc. TBD: What will this dialog look like?
The sender has encrypted this message and
no matching key was found to decrypt it.
If a message is received encrypted but no suitable key found to decrypt it,
then a message to that effect to should be displayed. A button can be
included to perform a search in the background, which would ideally
launch Seahorse or another existing app to perform the search. If the app
finds and adds the key, Geary should notice and decrypt the message.
A similar UI can be presented when encryption is not enabled for an account,
in which case the button should be labelled “Set up Encryption”, and also
TBD: have to check how this would work with Flatpak, if at all.
At startup, Geary should asynchronously load the list of keys with ultimate
trust via GPGME, and for each account, if one of its sender email addresses
matches a key will ultimate trust then enable encryption for that account.
No preferences are required here — they are already specified by the user's
email sender addresses and GPG configuration.
If no such keys match for an account, then the UX should mostly remain as
it is at the moment, unless a signed or encrypted message is received.
If possible, Geary should asynchronously monitor the users's GPG keys and
if a matching key with ultimate trust is created (or deleted) then the
account's status should be updated to match.
Signed and encrypting messages in the composer
